title: How to think about async and await in Lilos
I made a command-line tool designed to assist with polyrhythmic drum parts
description:
I‚Äôm a guitar player, and I use tablature notation editors such as Guitar Pro a lot. However, it gets complicated fast when I write polyrhythmic/polymetric drum parts, because shifts tend to go over the bar lines and it‚Äôs hard to make sense it‚Äôs correct visually (may be even harder if you listen to it). The other property of such parts is: it tends to unfold from simple ideas such as ‚ÄúI want to create a drum part that will have a 3 against 4 feel with a kick drum against a snare drum‚Äù. The other way to think about it is that it has a simple blueprint, but it‚Äôs tricky and error-prone to express in Western musical notation. This is why Polyrhythmix exists. I wanted to have a simple tool to workshop/brainstorm rhythmic ideas and evaluate them by having a MIDI playback. I‚Äôm into modern Progressive Rock/Metal music, Fusion, so it all applies very well. I have an impression it may be useful for Indian Carnatic music as well, but I would like to get some insightful confirmation on that.

Features:

  • drum track generation for polyrhythmic patterns of any complexity
  • midi-file output
  • generated bass lines can follow kick drum
description_plain:
I'm a guitar player, and I use tablature notation editors such as Guitar Pro a lot. However, it gets complicated fast when I write polyrhythmic/polymetric drum parts, because shifts tend to go over the bar lines and it's hard to make sense it's correct visually (may be even harder if you listen to it). The other property of such parts is: it tends to unfold from simple ideas such as "I want to create a drum part that will have a 3 against 4 feel with a kick drum against a snare drum". The other way to think about it is that it has a simple blueprint, but it's tricky and error-prone to express in Western musical notation. This is why `Polyrhythmix` exists. I wanted to have a simple tool to workshop/brainstorm rhythmic ideas and evaluate them by having a MIDI playback. I'm into modern Progressive Rock/Metal music, Fusion, so it all applies very well. I have an impression it may be useful for Indian Carnatic music as well, but I would like to get some insightful confirmation on that.

Features:
* drum track generation for polyrhythmic patterns of any complexity
* midi-file output
* generated bass lines can follow kick drum

What ad blocker do you use and why?
description:
I find myself once again setting up a new computer, and once again bummed that uBlock Origin doesn‚Äôt work for Safari. I remember ye olde controversy about uBlock, and the creation of uBlock Origin, but I haven‚Äôt kept up with any news about ad blockers at all. I remember the original value proposition of uBlock was resource efficiency. I vaguely remember that other ad blockers worked by injecting tons of CSS rules (?) and people said that wasn‚Äôt resource efficient.

What‚Äôs the current situation with ad blocking technology? Do the majority of them still work on goofy principles? Is there a real ‚Äúbest‚Äù answer for general use, or do you just install whatever and hope for the best?
description_plain:
I find myself once again setting up a new computer, and once again bummed that uBlock Origin doesn't work for Safari. I remember ye olde controversy about uBlock, and the creation of uBlock Origin, but I haven't kept up with any news about ad blockers at all. I remember the original value proposition of uBlock was resource efficiency. I vaguely remember that other ad blockers worked by injecting tons of CSS rules (?) and people said that wasn't resource efficient.

What's the current situation with ad blocking technology? Do the majority of them still work on goofy principles? Is there a real "best" answer for general use, or do you just install whatever and hope for the best?
